name: Algiers
fun_fact: Fun fact: Algiers is called 'Alger la Blanche' (Algiers the White) because of its stunning white Ottoman-era buildings that cascade down the hillside to the Mediterranean, creating a dazzling sight when viewed from the sea - a view that inspired countless artists and poets.

hero_dishes.name: Couscous with Lamb
hero_dishes.description: Fluffy hand-rolled semolina grains steamed over aromatic broth, topped with tender lamb and seven vegetables
hero_dishes.origin_story: Couscous is Algeria's national dish, traditionally made on Fridays. The Algerian version is distinct from Moroccan or Tunisian couscous - the grains are lighter and fluffier, and it's served with a rich vegetable soup on the side
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Restaurant Lalla Mina (Moorish architecture setting), Brasserie des FacultÃ©s, Les Orientalistes

hero_dishes.name: Mechoui
hero_dishes.description: Whole roast lamb cooked for hours until the meat is fall-off-the-bone tender with crispy, aromatic skin
hero_dishes.origin_story: Mechoui is the centerpiece of Algerian celebrations - traditionally cooked in outdoor ovens or over open fires for weddings and festivals. The version at Auberge Du Moulin is legendary among locals
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Auberge Du Moulin (24 Rue Abane Ramdane, Cheragua - very popular), Restaurant Lalla Mina

hero_dishes.name: Douara
hero_dishes.description: Sheep stomach cooked with chickpeas and Algerian spices until tender - rich, earthy, and deeply flavorful
hero_dishes.origin_story: Douara represents Algeria's nose-to-tail eating tradition, where nothing is wasted. When prepared properly with the right spice blend, it's considered a delicacy and a test of a cook's skill
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Algerian restaurants, street food markets in the Casbah

hero_dishes.name: Andalusian-Algerian Fusion
hero_dishes.description: Dishes combining Andalusian techniques with Algerian ingredients - a result of centuries of cultural exchange
hero_dishes.origin_story: When Muslims and Jews were expelled from Spain in 1492, many settled in Algiers, bringing Andalusian cooking techniques that merged with local Berber and Arab traditions to create a unique culinary style
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Le RepÃ¨re (in the historic Casbah), upscale restaurants blending traditions

signature_drinks.description: Sweet green tea with fresh mint leaves, poured from height to create a foam
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served throughout the day at cafÃ©s, after meals, and to guests as a sign of hospitality. The pouring ritual - from high above to create foam - is an art form

signature_drinks.name: Algerian Red Wine
signature_drinks.description: Full-bodied red wine from Algeria's historic vineyards planted during French colonial times
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served at restaurants like Jenina that cater to both locals and foreigners. Algeria was once one of the world's largest wine producers, and some excellent vineyards remain

food_culture_notes: Algerian cuisine is a mix of Berber, French, Arab, and Turkish flavors - one of North Africa's most complex culinary traditions
Friday couscous is a sacred tradition - families gather for this weekly feast
The Casbah's street food markets offer authentic local delicacies not found in restaurants
Hospitality is central to Algerian food culture - guests are always offered tea and food
